did.unittitle: Union League of Philadelphia Library, Art, and History and Archives Committee records

bioghist.p: The Union League of Philadelphia was founded in 1862 as a patriotic society to support the policies of President Abraham Lincoln. It evolved to its current identity as a non-sectarian and non-partisan private club. The Library Committee was one of the original Standing Committees. Its responsibilities have changed through time, including oversight of the publications which it assumed in 1893 and which was reassigned to Member Services in the late 1980s. At one time the Library Committee was also responsible for securing photographs of members. With the centennial observation in 1962, Max Whiteman was brought in and he eventually took charge of the library, art, artifact, and archives collections. In 1988 the Committee on Art, Archives, and History was absorbed into the Library Committee.

scopecontent.p: The series is arranged into three subseries: Library, Art, and History and Archives. The Library subseries includes minutes of the Library Committee; selected correspondence, financial statements, and annual reports; printed materials for library-sponsored events, including Library Hours; information on accessions and acquisitions; published catalogues of the library's collection; and copies of the library's newsletter, Vita Libris. The Art subseries includes minutes, correspondence, published catalogues, appraisals and information on loans. The History and Archives subseries includes pamphlets and articles on Union League history; published histories; printed materials and other files related to House Tours; files from the League's Oral History Project; files related to the publication of the Tanner manuscript While Lincoln Lay Dying; and miscellaneous research materials on various historical topics.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
